article:
]] An 'explosion crater' is a characteristically shaped hole formed when
material is ejected from the surface of the ground by an explosive event just
above, at, or below the surface.

A crater is formed by an explosive event through the displacement and ejection
of material from the ground. It is typically bowl-shaped. High pressure gas and
pressure waves are responsible for the creation of the crater by three processes
* plastic deformation of the ground
* projection of material (ejecta) from the ground by the expansion of gases in
  the ground
* spallation of the ground surface and two processes partially fill it back in
* fall-back of ejecta
* erosion and landslides of the crater lip and wall P. W.
  Cooper Explosives Engineering Wiley-VCH ISBN 0-471-18636-8 The relative
  importance of the five processes varies depending on the height above or depth
  below the ground surface at which the explosion occurs, and the material
  composing the ground.
